ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Filming, technical camera skills, story boarding, etc

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It is self motivated and self guided

This course's main weakness was that many of the screenings centered documentaries by and about older white men and women, often by documentarians within the professor's personal network. There was nothing wrong with this inherently, but it often felt very divorced from the work of students in the actual class. In addition, while the visiting artist format was a great portion of the class, some of the visiting artists that came to speak with the class failed to really enrich our understanding of the screened work or our personal practice. It was very helpful to see some of the films about more diverse subject matter, so maybe it would be a better structure if students had to submit their documentary topic during course enrollment and the professor took up the task of curating an invigorated and relevant list of films to screen. If not, the screenings should be optional and the in-class time should be mandatory. In this case, the course could benefit from more structured assignments. They could be small, but still give students a sense of structure as they approach such major projects. Potential assignments could be an opportunity for students to isolate and organize materials that are directly useful for their projects and make progress on filming and editing, whereas the screenings make up 3 hours of class time that could be spent working on our films.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would, but it would need to some heavy restructuring of content, teaching method, and range of assistants and support from various film makers and instructors.
Yes, film is great. Especially documentary film at Yale. Your homework is literally watching movies be for real
